title: 109_hr5058
content: The "Small Business Investment and Promotion Act of 2006" includes a temporary credit against income tax for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs. This credit is outlined in section 45N of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The excessive fuel cost credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the excess fuel cost paid for creditable fuel used in their trade or business. Excessive fuel cost is the amount paid for fuel minus the adjusted base price determined by the Secretary. The excessive fuel cost credit allows eligible taxpayers to claim the excess fuel cost paid for creditable fuel used in their trade or business. The applicable Labor Day 2004 price for fuel is determined by the Secretary and adjusted for inflation using data from the Energy Information Agency. The inflation adjustment is based on the monthly Consumer Price Index to reflect current inflation more accurately. Eligible taxpayers are defined for this purpose. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to individuals engaged in farming, commercial fishing, or small businesses with up to 50 employees. 'Creditable fuel' includes gasoline and diesel fuel. The text discusses eligible taxpayers who can elect a standard mileage allowance instead of a fuel credit for gasoline, diesel fuel, heating oil, and natural gas. The standard mileage rate is set at 60 cents per mile traveled. The section applies to fuels purchased within a 2-year period. The credit is part of the general business credit. The text introduces a new paragraph (27) for eligible taxpayers defined in section 45N(c) to claim the excessive fuel cost credit under section 45N(a). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The text introduces a temporary credit for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is a permanent extension of the research credit, with amendments applying to amounts paid or incurred after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Qualified restaurant property, retail improvement property, and certain systems in nonresidential buildings treated as 15-year property for depreciation deduction purposes. Qualified Restaurant Property and Qualified Retail Improvement Property are now treated as 15-year property for depreciation deduction purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments have been made to the definitions of 15-year property, including the removal of the requirement for property to be placed in service before January 1, 2006. Additionally, certain systems installed in nonresidential buildings are also included in this category. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now treats Qualified Restaurant Property and Qualified Retail Improvement Property as 15-year property for depreciation purposes. This includes improvements to nonresidential real property such as ventilation, air conditioning, and commercial refrigeration systems. The original use of the property must commence with the taxpayer. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now considers certain improvements to nonresidential real property as 15-year property for depreciation if they meet specific criteria. This includes improvements used by a trade or business with less than 50 employees, open to the general public, and placed in service more than 3 years after the building was first placed in service. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for certain improvements to nonresidential real property to be considered 15-year property for depreciation if they meet specific criteria, such as being used by a trade or business with less than 50 employees, open to the general public, and placed in service more than 3 years after the building was first placed in service. Amendments to the code include requirements for using the straight-line method and alternative systems for certain property classifications. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. Authorized appropriations for various programs under the Small Business Act and the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act for fiscal years 2007 and 2008. Authorized appropriations for the Manufacturing Extension Partnership program and Women's Business Center Program for fiscal years 2007 and 2008. $115,000,000 allocated for 2007 and $120,000,000 for 2008 for the Manufacturing Extension Partnership program, and $15,000,000 for 2007 and $15,500,000 for 2008 for the Women's Business Center Program. Congress should appropriate $79,000,000 for the 7(a) Loan Program under the Small Business Act. Additionally, funding should be allocated for various other small business programs at authorized levels. The next section discusses market-based adjustments in annual H-1B and H-2B nonimmigrant numerical limitations. Section 214(g) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to set the annual H-1B visa cap at 85,000 starting from fiscal year 2007. The H-1B visa cap was set at 85,000 starting from fiscal year 2007, with certain exceptions and limitations. The H-1B visa cap was set at 85,000 starting from fiscal year 2007, with certain exceptions and limitations. The numerical limitation for aliens subject to the cap may be adjusted if the total number of visas issued reaches the limit before the end of the fiscal year. The numerical limitation for H-1B visas may be adjusted if the cap is reached before the end of the fiscal year. Adjustments include a 20% increase in the first quarter and a 15% increase in the second quarter, with subsequent fiscal years set at 120% of the adjusted limitation. The numerical limitation for H-1B visas may be adjusted based on quarterly increases and set at 110-120% of the adjusted limitation for subsequent fiscal years. The adjusted numerical limitation for H-1B visas in a fiscal year can be set at 90% of the previous year's adjusted limitation if there is a shortfall not solely due to administrative reasons. This adjustment is based on the numerical limitation specified in paragraph (1)(A) and is effective as of October 1 of the fiscal year. The adjusted numerical limitation for H-1B visas in a fiscal year can be set at 90% of the previous year's adjusted limitation if there is a shortfall not solely due to administrative reasons. This adjustment applies to subparagraph (B) of paragraph (1) in the same manner as subparagraph (A) for the fiscal year. SEC. 8. SMALL BUSINESS CONTRACTING GOAL. Amends the Small Business Act to include contracts performed overseas in the small business contracting goal. Effective for fiscal years after September 30, 2006.
